quotes.topic_title: B2B indecision and delayed purchases
quotes.text: 40 to 60% of B2B purchase processes end in no decision.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A striking data point that frames indecision (not competition) as a primary obstacle in B2B buying.

quotes.topic_title: B2B indecision and delayed purchases
quotes.text: If you scratch on that data, the majority of those aren't saying, "Well, I'm not making a decision to buy something new because the old thing we were doing is better." That's not true at all.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: stalled deals often aren’t about preferring the status quo, but something else.

quotes.topic_title: B2B indecision and delayed purchases
quotes.text: In fact, the majority of those is they couldn't figure out how to make a choice confidently.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Pinpoints the core failure mode—lack of buyer confidence—which practitioners can address in positioning and sales enablement.

quotes.topic_title: B2B indecision and delayed purchases
quotes.text: So what they did was they just went to their boss and said, "You know what? Now's not a good time. Let's not do it now. Let's do it next year. Let's just delay it."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Shows the practical “escape hatch” buyers use when they can’t justify a decision, explaining why deals slip rather than close-lost.

quotes.topic_title: B2B indecision and delayed purchases
quotes.text: Because that is the safe risk-free thing for that person who's on the hook to make the decision to do.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Highlights the personal-risk dynamic behind delays, implying messaging should reduce perceived career risk for the buyer.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The book guides you through a better way to pitch and sell your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets an actionable promise that the episode will provide a concrete approach to improving pitching and selling.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And in our conversation, April shares the framework that she has seen work most often in getting potential customers to get excited about your product and to decide to buy your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable framework aimed at driving customer excitement and purchase decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Like I say, at the top of this episode, you'll become better at pitching and selling your product by the end of this episode.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear outcome statement that frames the episode as skill-building with immediate practitioner value.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Algorithmic trading has historically been reserved for the hedge fund elite. Now with Composer, you can automate your trading with a library of over 1000 strategies that are easy to understand and tweak using an AI assistant and visual editor.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 1
quotes.context: Highlights a practical way to operationalize algorithmic trading via a large strategy library plus AI-assisted customization without needing deep expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Composer is the first ever algorithmic trading platform where you don't need any coding experience.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 1
quotes.context: A counterintuitive positioning claim that reframes algorithmic trading as accessible to non-technical practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Composer also has a powerful back tester to see the historical performance of your strategies, and you can then invest with a single click.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 1
quotes.context: Emphasizes an actionable workflow: validate a strategy with backtesting, then deploy it immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With $1 billion in trading volume and over 1 million trades executed, composer already has many big time investors using the platform regularly.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 1
quotes.context: Provides concrete adoption metrics that can be used to assess traction and credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click through metrics and instead use your north star metrics like activation, retention, subscription and payments.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 1
quotes.context: A practical measurement model for experimentation: optimize against North Star outcomes rather than shallow engagement metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Return guest and book focus
quotes.text: The secret is a lot of work.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that sustainable growth and craft (including pitching) comes from consistent effort, not hacks.

quotes.topic_title: Return guest and book focus
quotes.text: So my background is, I do positioning work.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Sets up the lens for the episode: sales pitching as an extension of positioning, not just persuasion tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Return guest and book focus
quotes.text: And so in the work that I do with clients, generally what we're working on is a shift in the positioning, which is a little bit of a shift in our thinking around, how do we win in the market?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Defines positioning work as clarifying the strategy for winning—useful for practitioners to anchor messaging in competitive advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Return guest and book focus
quotes.text: So in order to test that positioning, what we want to do is take the positioning and translate it into a sales pitch and then test it live with prospects.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A practical methodology: treat the sales pitch as a real-world test harness for positioning, validated directly with prospects.

quotes.topic_title: Why most SaaS pitches fail: feature tours
quotes.text: So in order to test that positioning, what we want to do is take the positioning and translate it into a sales pitch and then test it live with prospects.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A practical methodology: validate positioning by operationalizing it into a pitch and testing it in real sales conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Why most SaaS pitches fail: feature tours
quotes.text: for the most part what was happening in the sales pitch is there was no positioning going on in the sales pitch at all. The sales pitch was essentially a product exposition, so essentially a glorified product box room.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A diagnosis of why many SaaS pitches fail: they default to showing the product instead of answering “why pick us?”.

quotes.topic_title: Why most SaaS pitches fail: feature tours
quotes.text: And so what I wanted to do was build a pitch structure that would reflect the positioning.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A clear directive for practitioners: the pitch should be designed as an expression of positioning, not a generic demo flow.

quotes.topic_title: Why most SaaS pitches fail: feature tours
quotes.text: And when we're talking about features, we shouldn't be talking about features. We should be talking about the value that the features deliver.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A simple rule for improving pitches: translate feature talk into customer value outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why most SaaS pitches fail: feature tours
quotes.text: Help Scout said, "Well, you know what? Customer service for that kind of business is really important. It's the only time you ever get to interact with actual customers."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A concrete positioning example reframing customer service from a support function into a primary customer interaction channel for digital businesses.

quotes.topic_title: Help Scout example: before-and-after pitch
quotes.text: The problem with that pitch is the customer's sitting there going, "I don't know, man, that sounds a little bit like my shared inbox, but it also sounds like help desk software. Is it different than help desk software? I'm not so sure. And there's overlap in the features there."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford 2.0
quotes.context: Explains why feature-first demos fail: they blur category boundaries and create confusion versus alternatives.

quotes.topic_title: Help Scout example: before-and-after pitch
quotes.text: And so it doesn't really answer the question, why pick us over the other guys?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford 2.0
quotes.context: A crisp diagnostic for evaluating any pitch: does it clearly justify selection over competitors and substitutes?

quotes.topic_title: Help Scout example: before-and-after pitch
quotes.text: And so a different style of pitch would be one, we would do a little bit of setup to give everybody an idea about how we fit amongst all the other solutions and what our point of view is in the market. And then when we get to exploring the features, we would do that within the context of the differentiated value.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford 2.0
quotes.context: Provides a practical methodology: market framing first, then feature demo anchored to differentiated value.

quotes.topic_title: Help Scout example: before-and-after pitch
quotes.text: That pitch is designed to answer the question, "Why pick us over the other folks?"
quotes.speaker: April Dunford 2.0
quotes.context: Defines the core purpose of positioning-led pitching as decision support, not product exposition.

quotes.topic_title: Sales Pitch framework: setup and follow-through
quotes.text: So first of all, the pitch structure has two big pieces. So the first is the setup. The setup piece is not about us, it's about the market, our point of view on the market. The second bit is all about our differentiated value.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Defines the core two-part sales pitch model and clarifies that the setup is market-centric, not product-centric.

quotes.topic_title: Sales Pitch framework: setup and follow-through
quotes.text: So those pieces aren't equal. In a normal sales pitch situation, we don't want to spend all day in the setup part. We want to get to the meat, which is our differentiated value, but we can't skip that bit.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on balancing brevity in setup with the necessity of establishing context before differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Sales Pitch framework: setup and follow-through
quotes.text: And we could break the upfront into three pieces. So it starts with our insight into the market. So you can think of this as our point of view on the market or kind of like the problem inside the problem, in some ways.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Introduces a practical three-part setup structure starting with a compelling market insight framing.

quotes.topic_title: Sales Pitch framework: setup and follow-through
quotes.text: But just kind of like can we agree that if we really wanted to solve this problem and knowing what works and doesn't work in the alternate solutions, can we agree really good solutions should tick these boxes? This is getting the customer aligned with your worldview.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Shows how to use “perfect world” criteria to align prospects to your positioning before presenting your product.

quotes.topic_title: Sales Pitch framework: setup and follow-through
quotes.text: And so we handle that at the end in this special objection step. And then we end the pitch with what I call the ask, which is whatever we want the customer to do next.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Provides a clear sequencing tactic: proactively address silent objections, then explicitly drive the next step with an ask.

quotes.topic_title: Handling objections and doing discovery in-pitch
quotes.text: And so if you've got a point of view on the world and you're talking to a customer that just fundamentally doesn't agree with that... In the case of a Help Scout, they come in and they say, "No, actually it's a cost center for us. We're just trying to get the cost down." They should disqualify that deal because they can't serve that customer better than Zendesk does. Zendesk is going to win that deal.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A clear example of treating fundamental worldview misalignment as a disqualifier rather than an objection to overcome.

quotes.topic_title: Handling objections and doing discovery in-pitch
quotes.text: But if you've done this properly, your insight should resonate for the target account that you're trying to go after.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A positioning test: if your opening insight doesn’t land, you may be talking to the wrong target customer.

quotes.topic_title: Handling objections and doing discovery in-pitch
quotes.text: The beginning of the sales pitch thing... One more thing on that is that part of what we're doing in that setup is what salespeople would call discovery.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Reframes the pitch setup as a structured discovery phase, not just a monologue.

quotes.topic_title: Handling objections and doing discovery in-pitch
quotes.text: And so that setup part should not be me talking at you. It should be a conversation between me and the client saying, "Do you agree with this? Is this what you're seeing? Did you start with a shared inbox? What are you doing right now? Did you ever consider using help desk software? Why yes, why no? Do you have any constraints on what you're looking at? What have you tried before? What are you looking at trying right now?"
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Provides a practical script of discovery questions to validate fit and surface objections early inside the pitch structure.

quotes.topic_title: Handling objections and doing discovery in-pitch
quotes.text: So by the time we get to the end of the setup, we should either be aligned like, "Yep, this looks like a good prospect for us. Yep, we can do something. Yep, they got a problem we can solve. This all looks good." Or we kind of jointly come to the conclusion, "Hey, this just... Our stuff just ain't for you, man." And that's it.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A decision-gate methodology: use the setup to reach explicit alignment—or mutually disqualify—before proceeding.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching mindset: help buyers understand the market
quotes.text: I think one of the biggest shift maybe from this framework is that you go into a teaching mindset. It's not just like, "Here's our product, it's going to solve your problem." It's more, "Here's what's happening broadly. Maybe you don't have the time to do the research we've done. Here's what we found."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical positioning shift: lead with market education and synthesized research rather than a product pitch.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching mindset: help buyers understand the market
quotes.text: What I don't have is a clear picture of the market. What are the different approaches to this problem? Forget about products. What are the approaches to the problem? Where do the products fit in those approaches? What's a good solution for me look like? What should be my purchase criteria?" That's really hard for buyers to figure out.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A buyer-centric mental model: help prospects map the market (approaches, fit, criteria) before talking features.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching mindset: help buyers understand the market
quotes.text: But if you look at the research on this stuff, the research doesn't support that. The research actually says what B2B software buyers want in a sales interaction is perspectives on the market and help weighing their options. And we don't do that. We're just like, "Here's our stuff. You figure it out, it's up to you. You figure it out."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance: buyers want your market perspective and option-weighing help, despite fears of seeming biased.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching mindset: help buyers understand the market
quotes.text: And so the data on this shows that for B2B, 40 to 60% of B2B purchase processes end in no decision.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A concrete data point underscoring that buyer overwhelm often leads to stalled deals rather than competitive losses.

quotes.topic_title: No-decision problem and buyer risk psychology
quotes.text: And so the data on this shows that for B2B, 40 to 60% of B2B purchase processes end in no decision.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A concrete data point that reframes the core problem as “no decision” rather than losing to competitors.

quotes.topic_title: No-decision problem and buyer risk psychology
quotes.text: In fact, the majority of those is they couldn't figure out how to make a choice confidently.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Pinpoints the real blocker behind stalled deals: confidence in choosing, not preference for the status quo.

quotes.topic_title: No-decision problem and buyer risk psychology
quotes.text: The way we combat that is not just talking about ourselves, it's actually about trying to be helpful to that person in this very stressful situation that is trying to figure out how do I make a really good decision.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for positioning and sales: shift from self-focused pitching to decision support for the buyer.

quotes.topic_title: No-decision problem and buyer risk psychology
quotes.text: So what we should be doing is giving them a way to think about the whole market and say, in the case of Help Scout, "Look, there's shared inbox and then there's help desk software and then there's us. And I don't care who the vendor is, I'm going to put them in one of those buckets."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A practical market-framing framework (bucket the market) that reduces buyer cognitive load and increases decision confidence.

quotes.topic_title: No-decision problem and buyer risk psychology
quotes.text: we lose an awful lot of deals to just plain customer indecision, customers being more afraid of screwing up than missing out.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A counterintuitive buyer-risk psychology insight that explains why urgency/FOMO messaging often fails in B2B.

quotes.topic_title: Why FOMO pressure backfires; reduce perceived risk
quotes.text: And so what his data showed is if a customer is indecisive, throwing FOMO into the mix makes it worse. So they're less likely to close the deal if you throw that in.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Contrarian, data-backed takeaway: FOMO pressure can reduce close rates specifically for indecisive buyers.

quotes.topic_title: Why FOMO pressure backfires; reduce perceived risk
quotes.text: And the idea is that they're already stressed out and you're just putting more stress on them by pressuring them, by saying, "Oh, this is happening, bad things are going to..." You're like, "Bad things will happen if I do something, bad things happen if I don't do something, what do I do?"
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism behind why urgency backfires: it increases perceived downside on both action and inaction, causing paralysis.

quotes.topic_title: Why FOMO pressure backfires; reduce perceived risk
quotes.text: So what does work in that situation is, one, giving them the tools to make the decision. So that includes paint the picture of the market, teaching them how to buy essentially.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable framework shift: replace pressure with enablement by educating buyers on how to evaluate and decide.

quotes.topic_title: Why FOMO pressure backfires; reduce perceived risk
quotes.text: So this idea of being able to take risk off the table is a really serious one if we've got a customer that is actually paralyzed because of this indecision thing.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Practical guidance: de-risking (guarantees, support, smaller steps) is a primary lever to unblock indecisive customers.

quotes.topic_title: Champion’s job: decide safely and build consensus
quotes.text: And so one of the things I think of is normally when we come at this we're like, "Well, how can we convince the customer that we do the job that they need to have done?" And obviously we need to do that, but there is this secondary job that the champion of the deal is, and that's how do I make a decision without getting fired? And so we got to help them accomplish that job, otherwise we don't get what we want, which is the money.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Reframes B2B selling as helping the internal champion make a safe, defensible decision—not just proving product value.

quotes.topic_title: Champion’s job: decide safely and build consensus
quotes.text: Well, this is the thing, it's so easy to default to the market leader in that situation. The market leader has this big advantage that you can say, "You know what? Who's going to get me in trouble for picking Salesforce? Nobody." It's so easy to just flip back on that. And so if you're the challenger in this situation, the brand that's number two or number three, you've got to get over all of this inertia and tilting towards the status quo, because it's just so easy, it's the lowest risk decision, besides do nothing is to just pick the leader in the market and we'll just run with that.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Explains why challengers lose to incumbents: buyers optimize for perceived career risk, so you must counter status-quo inertia.

quotes.topic_title: Champion’s job: decide safely and build consensus
quotes.text: Now, the other people can't make a deal happen, but they can kill it a thousand ways.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for multi-stakeholder B2B buying: many blockers, few true drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Champion’s job: decide safely and build consensus
quotes.text: But once the deal is cooking it is on you to arm that champion to handle all the objections potentially of all the other groups.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: equip the champion with objection-handling ammo to build internal consensus across stakeholders.

quotes.topic_title: Champion’s job: decide safely and build consensus
quotes.text: and so we're not actually pitching value to those people, we're just handling objections.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Clarifies stakeholder-specific messaging: for groups like IT, success is removing blockers (security/integration), not selling ROI.

quotes.topic_title: Arming champions with objection-handling materials
quotes.text: Well, if we're really smart, we already know because we've done lots of deals.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A simple mental model: use pattern recognition from past deals to proactively surface and neutralize objections early.

quotes.topic_title: Arming champions with objection-handling materials
quotes.text: So if we're being a good partner in this, sometimes even in the very first meeting in that spot where we're talking about objectives, we're going to say, "Hey, look, IT is going to come in and they're going to be worried about this, this, and this, and don't worry, we got you."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable tactic: pre-handle predictable stakeholder blockers (like IT/security) in the first meeting to keep momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Arming champions with objection-handling materials
quotes.text: And you might have other things like you're going to take this to your boss and they're going to want to know ROI numbers, blah, blah, blah, and we've already done that, look, here's our calculator, if you give us this information, we can put this in, here's how you sell your boss.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Concrete enablement example: provide tools (ROI calculator + talk track) that help the champion sell internally.

quotes.topic_title: Arming champions with objection-handling materials
quotes.text: So that's what we're doing. We're trying to arm them because we've done a million deals, they've never bought software like this before.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Reframes sales enablement as asymmetric expertise: your job is to transfer deal-navigation know-how to inexperienced buyers.

quotes.topic_title: Arming champions with objection-handling materials
quotes.text: I don't think we need a ton of resources to do it, but I do think we need to have enough traction in the market that we understand how a deal typically goes.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Counterintuitive constraint: you don’t need a big team—just enough deal history to predict the buying process and objections.

quotes.topic_title: Applicability to early-stage teams and founders
quotes.text: Yeah. So here's what I think, the core of a good sales pitch is really deeply understanding your differentiated value, which is what is the value I can deliver that no other solution can.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Defines a practical mental model for sales and product alignment: start with differentiated value, not messaging or features.

quotes.topic_title: Applicability to early-stage teams and founders
quotes.text: And so the first step in fixing this I think is to have a cross-functional team work on positioning.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable recommendation that positioning should be built jointly by product, marketing, and sales rather than in silos.

quotes.topic_title: Applicability to early-stage teams and founders
quotes.text: So if I've got product, marketing, and sales together in the room working on defining what our differentiated value is, then I'm going to get all the good juice out of the product team that deeply understands the product, deeply understand what's differentiated about it, deeply understands value, and then I'm also going to have all the juice from the sales team that understands what the common objections are, what the champion really wants to get done and doesn't want to get done, what the situation is in a typical account, and then all of this cool information sharing happens, which actually you end up with way better definition of your differentiated value in the first place.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism for better positioning: combine product’s value knowledge with sales’ objection and buyer-context knowledge to sharpen differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Applicability to early-stage teams and founders
quotes.text: What typically happens is product's working on some stuff, sales is working on some stuff, marketing's working on some stuff. Marketing in their own little bubble comes up with positioning, they might build some stuff for the sales team, heave it over to the sales team. Sales team looks at it and says, "I don't get what any of this stuff is. I disagree with this. This doesn't match what I see," and they just throw it out and they go back to doing the same pitch they've been doing since the year of the flood.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Contrasts the common (broken) handoff model with a collaborative approach, highlighting why positioning often fails to stick in sales.

quotes.topic_title: Defining differentiated value and linking to insight
quotes.text: Yeah. So differentiated value is the answer to the question why pick us over the other alternatives?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Defines differentiated value in a simple, decision-oriented way that teams can use to pressure-test positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Defining differentiated value and linking to insight
quotes.text: And so the way we get at that in positioning is we start with putting a stake in the ground of who do we actually compete with? And so if we didn't exist in the market, what would a customer do?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Gives a practical method for identifying real competitive alternatives, including the status quo, not just direct rivals.

quotes.topic_title: Defining differentiated value and linking to insight
quotes.text: And then what we do is we go down that list of features and we say, "So what? You got advanced AI, whatever the heck the thing is, so what? Why does anybody care?" And the answer to that so what is your value.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Introduces the repeatable “so what” chain to translate features into customer value rooted in differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Defining differentiated value and linking to insight
quotes.text: The insight is basically the context that makes your differentiated value important, what is the thing you need to know to understand the importance of my differentiated value?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Connects positioning to messaging by defining insight as the framing that makes differentiation matter.

quotes.topic_title: Defining differentiated value and linking to insight
quotes.text: If the differentiated value doesn't work in a sales pitch, what you'll get is the company going, "Why would I pay for that? This is not value for me, buddy."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Provides a concrete real-world test for whether your differentiated value is compelling: it should survive buyer scrutiny in a pitch.
